questions.text: Transport of lipid-soluble substances across the cell membrane occurs via which of the following?
questions.solution:
Lipid-soluble substances are transported across the cell membrane via diffusion.

  • The rate of diffusion depends directly on lipid solubility.
  • Characteristics of simple diffusion
    • The only form of transport that is not carrier-mediated
    • Occurs down an electrochemical gradient (“downhill”)
    • Does not require metabolic energy and therefore is passive
  • Permeability
    • Describes the ease with which a solute diffuses through a membrane
    • Depends on the characteristics of the solute and the membrane
  • Small hydrophobic solutes (e.g., O2) have the highest permeabilities in lipid membranes.
  • Hydrophilic solutes (e.g., Na+) must cross cell membranes through water-filled channels, or pores. If the solute is an ion, then its flux will depend on both the concentration difference and the potential difference across the membrane.

Related Pearl: Transport across the cell membrane

questions.text: Which of the following will diffuse more rapidly through phospholipid membranes?
questions.solution:
Among the following substances, oxygen diffuses more rapidly through phospholipid membranes as it is a lipid-soluble substance. 

Phospholipid membranes are:

  • Permeable to lipid-soluble substances (e.g., O2, CO2, NH3, steroid hormones)
  • Impermeable to water-soluble substances (e.g., Na+, Cl-, glucose)
  • Semipermeable to water

questions.text: Which of the following is explained by the fick’s law of diffusion?
questions.solution:
Fick’s law of diffusion explains passive diffusion along the concentration gradient. 

Fick’s law of diffusion: The magnitude of the diffusing tendency is directly proportional to the cross-sectional area across which diffusion is taking place and the concentration gradient, or chemical gradient, which is the difference in concentration of the diffusing substance divided by the thickness of the membrane.

Related Pearl: Factors influencing the rate of net diffusion of a substance across a membrane

Fick’s Law of Diffusion → J = -DA (Δc/Δx)

where,

J is the net rate of diffusion,

D is the diffusion coefficient,

A is the area, and

Δc/Δx is the concentration gradient.

Factors Effect on diffusion
↑ Thickness of the membrane ↓
↑ Lipid Solubility ↑
↑ Temperature ↑
↑  Size of the molecule ↓
↑  Area of the Membrane ↑
↑ Distribution of Protein Channels ↑

questions.text: For a membrane permeable substance, the intracellular concentration (IC) is 10 units and extracellular concentration (EC) is 5 units. If the intracellular concentration, surface area of the membrane and thickness of the membrane are doubled, and the EC remains the same, What will be the net effect on the diffusion?
questions.solution:
The net effect on the diffusion is, it becomes 3x.

The magnitude of the diffusion: 

where,
  • J = net rate of diffusion
  • D = diffusion coefficient
  • A = area of the membrane
  • Δx = thickness of the membrane or the distance the molecule must travel across for diffusion
  • Δc = concentration gradient

In the condition mentioned above, the surface area, the thickness of the membrane and intracellular concentration becomes doubled. This means,

  • A is doubled = 2A
  • Δx is doubled = 2Δx
  • IC is doubled. 10x2= 20 units; EC is 5 units.

So, Δc = 20 - 5 = 15. Δc was 5 with the original concentrations. Hence Δc has been tripled.

Now,

J=-D x 2A x 3Δc/2Δx = 3 x [DA Δc/Δx]

Therefore the diffusion of the substance increases by three-fold.

2nd method :

J = - DA (Δc / Δx )
After applying changes,Δc = intracellular conc. - extracellular conc.     = 10 - 5    = 5

Therefore, J1 = - DA (5 / Δx )

After appropriate doublings,      New intracellular conc. = 10 * 2 = 20      New extracellular conc. = 5 (since no change)     Δc = 20 - 5 = 15

Therefore, J2 = - D 2*A (15 / 2*Δx )                  

                   = - D A (15 / Δx )

Now,     J2  / J1 = [- DA (15 / Δx ) ] / [ = - DA (5 / Δx ) ]    

            J2  / J1  = 15 / 5 

                         = 3

Therefore the diffusion of the substance increases by three-fold.

questions.text: Which of the following does not follow transport saturation kinetics?
questions.solution:
Simple diffusion is not carrier-mediated transport hence do not follow saturation kinetics.

  • Facilitated diffusion, primary active transport, and secondary active transport all involve integral membrane proteins and are called carrier-mediated transport.
  • All carrier-mediated transport system follows saturation kinetics.
  • The figure shows that as the concentration of the diffusing substance increases, the rate of simple diffusion continues to increase proportionately, but in the case of facilitated diffusion, the rate of diffusion cannot rise greater than the transport maximum (Tm). Tm is analogous to the maximum velocity (Vmax) level in enzyme kinetics.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Carrier Mediated Transport

Properties Description
Stereospecificity For example- D-Glucose is transport by facilitated diffusion but not L-isomer. Simple diffusion in contrast will not distinguish between the two.
Saturation The transport rate increases as the concentration of the solute increases until the carriers are saturated (Tm).
Competition Structurally related solutes compete for transport sites on carrier molecules.

questions.text: Which statement about the facilitated diffusion is true?
questions.solution:
When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

Examples

  • GLUT
  • Urea Transporters :
    • UTA 1, 2, 3, 4 in Kidney
    • UTB in RBC
  • Amino Acid Transporters

Other options are wrong because: 

  • Facilitated diffusion is a type of passive transport.
  • It follows saturation kinetics. 
  • No energy input is required in facilitated diffusion.

questions.text: The movement of which of the following substance across the membrane is most affected by osmotic pressure?
questions.solution:
The movement of water across the membrane is most affected by osmotic pressure.

Osmotic pressure is the pressure that would have to be applied to prevent the movement of water molecules to the more concentrated solution i.e. to a region in which there is higher concentration of a solute to which the membrane is impermeable.

  • Osmotic pressure is calculated by Vant Hoff’s law.

questions.text: Osmolarity is defined as _______
questions.solution:
Difference between osmolarity & osmolality:

  • Osmolarity is the number of osmoles per litre of solution,
  • Osmolality is the number of osmoles per kilogram of solvent.
  • Therefore, osmolarity is affected by the volume of the various solutes in the solution and the temperature, while the osmolality is not.

questions.text: Passive transfer of only solvent occurs in ______
questions.solution:
Passive transfer of the only solvent occurs in Osmosis.

The diffusion of solvent molecules into a region in which there is a higher concentration of a solute to which the membrane is impermeable is called osmosis.

Note: Membrane is impermeable to the solute.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic man takes a low-dose aspirin daily due to cardiovascular risk. The absorption of aspirin in the stomach is an example of which type of transport?
questions.solution:
The absorption of salicylates like aspirin in the stomach is an example of nonionic diffusion.

  • Some weak acids and bases are quite soluble in cell membranes in the undissociated form, but they cannot cross membranes in the charged (i.e. dissociated) form. Consequently, molecules of the undissociated substance diffuse from one side of the membrane to the other and then dissociate. This phenomenon is called nonionic diffusion.

Examples

  • Ammonia excretion in collecting ducts
  • Excretion of weak acids and bases in the kidney
  • Absorption of salicylates in the stomach
  • Absorption of bile acids in the distal ileum

questions.text: Energy is required in which of the following mode of transport.
questions.solution: When a carrier protein transports substances against their electrical and chemical gradients (uphill movement) it requires energy and this type of transport is called active transport.

questions.text: Movement of calcium from the cytosol to the extracellular space takes place by
questions.solution:
The movement of calcium from the cytosol to the extracellular space takes place by primary active transport. 

Two primary active transport calcium pumps maintain low intracellular calcium levels. One pumps calcium ions to the extracellular space and another to the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

Calcium transport also takes place via secondary active transport. A sodium-calcium exchanger/antiporter moves sodium ions to the interior and calcium ions to the exterior.

questions.text: Na+-K+ ATP pump uses ________
questions.solution:
Na+- K+ ATPase or Na+-K+ ATP pump catalyzes the hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and uses the energy to extrude three Na+ from the cell and take two K+ into the cell for each molecule of ATP hydrolyzed.

Sodium-Potassium Pump/ Na+– K+ Pump:

  • Carrier protein located on the plasma membrane of all cells
  • Pumps 3 Na+ out of the cell & 2 K+ into the cell (coupling ratio 3:2)
    • 2 separate globular proteins:
      • Larger- α subunit & smaller- β subunit, α subunit concerned with Na+- K+ transport
  • Binding sites on α subunit:
    • 3 intracellular sites- for Na+, ATP, and one phosphorylation site
    • 2 extracellular sites- for K+ and oubain

Mechanism Of Action

Functions:

  • Controlling Cell Volume.
  • Electrogenic Nature- maintains Resting membrane potential
  • The energy from the Na+–K+ pump also indirectly serves as the energy source for secondary active transport.

Regulation:

  • Pump activity is altered by second messenger molecules eg. cAMP, DAG
  • Stimulated by thyroid hormones, insulin and aldosterone
  • Inhibition by dopamine ,digitalis glycosides, ouabain

questions.text: Primary active transport is mediated by which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
In active transport the energy is provided almost exclusively by the hydrolysis of ATP. Hence many carrier molecules are ATPases (eg. Na+-K+-ATPase), enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of ATP.

PRIMARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT SECONDARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT
Requires direct input of metabolic energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)   The transport of two or more solutes is coupled and metabolic energy is provided  indirectly from the Na+ gradient that is maintained across cell membranes by Na+-K+-ATPase pump

a) Na+-K+-ATPase or sodium potassium pump

b) Ca2+ -ATPase

c) H+-ATPase or proton pump d)      H+-K+-ATPase

a) Na+- glucose cotransport

b) Na+-Ca2+ counter transport

questions.text: For Na+-K+ ATPase coupling ratio is _____
questions.solution:
Na+-K+ ATPase or Na+-K+ ATP pump is an electrogenic pump in that it moves three positive charges out of the cell for each two that it moves in, and it is therefore said to have a coupling ratio of 3:2.

Note:

  • Na+-K+ ATP pump is found in almost all parts of the body, and it catalyzes the hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and uses the energy for its activity
  • It is one of the major energy using process in the body. On an average, it accounts for 24% of the energy utilized by the cells, and in neurons it accounts for 70%. Thus, it accounts for large share in basal metabolism

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man has been prescribed empagliflozin. Which of the following processes will most likely be affected by this drug?
questions.solution:
Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor. SGLT-2 or sodium-glucose transport protein 2 is an example of a cotransporter that plays a key role in glucose absorption from renal tubule by secondary active transport. This process is blocked by SGLT-2 inhibitors, leading to renal loss of glucose and improved glycemic control.

  • A special property of the transport protein involved in secondary active transport is that a conformational change to allow Na+ movement to the interior will not occur until a glucose molecule also attaches to the transport protein. When they both become attached, the conformational change takes place automatically, and the Na+ and glucose are transported to the inside of the cell at the same time.
  • The figure shows glucose is transported uphill and Na+ is transported downhill. Energy derived from the downhill movement of Na+ is maintained by the Na+-K+ ATPase pump on the basolateral side.

questions.text: Glucose is absorbed in intestine by?
questions.solution:
Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport (sodium co-transport).

The energy for glucose transport is provided indirectly, by the active transport of Na+ out of the cell. This maintains the concen­tration gradient across the luminal border of the cell so that more Na+ and consequently more glucose enter.

Though both secondary active transport and facilitated diffusion play a role in glucose absorption, it is the initial active transport of sodium through the basolateral membranes of the intestinal epithelial cells that provide the eventual force for moving glucose through the membranes as well. So, secondary active transport is the single best answer for this question.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady is diagnosed with Lambart- Eaton syndrome. Radioimmunoassay reveals the presence of serum antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels. Which of the following process will be affected as a result of this pathology?
questions.solution:
Exocytosis of neurotransmitters at the nerve terminals will be affected as a result of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels.

After an action potential reaches the terminal endings of a nerve, the influx of Ca2+ via voltage-gated calcium channels leads to the fusion of intracellular vesicles with cell membranes. This results in the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic space. This process will be impaired in the case of Lambert-eaton syndrome.

Exocytosis is the extrusion of membrane-bound vesicles. In exocytosis, intracellular vesicles move to the cell membrane, fuse with it and then release their contents to the extracellular fluid. Solute and water can be released from the cell via vesicles by the process of exocytosis.

Exocytosis can be:

Constitutive exocytosis:

  • Involves prompt transport of proteins to the cell membrane in vesicles, with little or no processing or storage
  • Examples
    • Goblet cells in the intestine continuously to release mucus
    • Fibroblasts in connective tissue release collagen

Regulated/ Non constitutive exocytosis:

  • Here the proteins from golgi apparatus initially enter the secretory granules, where the processing of prohormones to mature hormones occurs before exocytosis
  • Examples
    • Endocrine cells, hormones are stored in secretory vesicles and released in response to a signal from outside the cell.
    • To insert proteins into the cell membrane like aquaporin insertion

Note:

  • The term ‘regulated exocytosis’ is misleading because even constitutive exocytosis is regulated.
  • Exocytosis involves two families of proteins: Rabs, which help vesicles dock onto the membrane, and SNAREs, which facilitate membrane fusion.
  • This is Ca2+ -dependent process
  • Exocytosis, like endocytosis, requires energy in the form of ATP.

questions.text: Which pathway is called regulated pathway?
questions.solution:
The non constitutive pathway of exocytosis is called the regulated pathway.

Exocytosis can be either constitutive or non constitutive(regulated):

  • Regulated or nonconstitutive pathway: Proteins from the Golgi apparatus initially enter secretory granules, where processing of prohormones to the mature hormones occurs before exocytosis.
  • Constitutive pathway: Involves the prompt transport of proteins to the cell membrane in vesicles, with little or no processing or storage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old gentleman is diagnosed with elevated blood cholesterol levels. A defect in a process that involves the protein 'clathrin' is being suspected. Which of the following process will be most likely affected by this defect?
questions.solution:
Receptor-mediated endocytosis takes place in coated pits or indentations where the cytoplasmic side of the membrane has high concentrations of protein. The most common protein found in coated pits is clathrin.

A GTP binding protein dynamin is involved in pinching off the vesicle formed in clathrin-mediated endocytosis

 

Importance:

  • Internalisation of many receptors and ligands bound to them eg. LDL, Nerve Growth Factor.
  • Receptor-mediated endocytosis transports a variety of substances including protein hormones, growth factors, antibodies, and plasma proteins that serve as carriers for iron and cholesterol.
  • Synaptic function
  • Abnormalities in receptor-mediated removal of cholesterol from the blood are associated with elevated plasma cholesterol levels and cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about secretory vesicle transport?
questions.solution:
Vesicular transport has no relation to the concentration gradient.

Vesicular transport requires energy expenditure by the cell, so this is an active method of membrane transport. Energy is needed to accomplish vesicle formation and vesicle movement within the cell.

 

METHOD OF TRANSPORT SUBSTANCE INVOLVED ENERGY REQUIREMENT
Endocytosis

Uptake of fluids or macromolecules by the cell

  
  1. Pinocytosis

Substances ingested are in the solution

Small molecules are taken up by invaginations of the plasma membrane and pinch off to form a vesicle.

    2. Phagocytosis

 Multimolecular particles (e.g bacteria, cellular debris) Active. The cell extends pseudopods around the particle to form a vesicle.
    3. Receptor-mediated Specific large polar molecule (ex: Transferrin, LDL) Active. Molecules bind to receptors that are localized in clathrin-coated pits in the plasma membrane, endocytosed in vesicles that fuse with lysosomes
Transcytosis

Intact proteins across epithelial barriers (e.g., ingested antibodies in maternal milk across intestinal epithelia)

Movement of endocytosed vesicles between the apical and basolateral compartments of cells.
Exocytosis Secretary products (e.g hormones, enzymes), as well as large molecules that pass through the cell intact. Active. An increase in cytosolic Ca2+ induces the fusion of a secretory vesicle with the plasma membrane; the vesicle opens up and releases its contents.

questions.text: Transcytosis occurs in which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
Transcytosis is seen in epithelial cells of intestine. Transcytosis is endocytosis across one membrane of the cell followed by exocytosis across the opposite membrane.

Transcytosis across epithelia or endothelia: Some molecules, such as proteins, are too large to diffuse through the membrane or cross the membrane transporters of epithelia. Instead they are moved across epithelia by transcytosis.

Steps:

  • The molecule is brought into the epithelial cell via receptor-mediated endocytosis.
  • The resulting vesicle attaches to microtubules in the cells cytoskeleton and is transported across the cell by vesicular transport.
  • At the opposite side of the epithelium, the contents of the vesicle are expelled into the interstitial fluid by exocytosis.

Significance:

  • Transcytosis makes it possible for large proteins to move across an epithelium and remain intact.
  • It is the means by which infants absorb maternal antibodies in breast milk. The antibodies are absorbed on the apical surface of the infant’s intestinal epithelium and then released into the extracellular fluid.

questions.text: Which of the following ion is used in exocytosis?
questions.solution: As exocytosis, begins → ↑in intracellular Ca2+ → Ca2+interacts with a calcium sensing protein → secretory vesicle docking and fusion → fused area of membrane opens, the vesicle contents diffuse into the extracellular fluid while the vesicle membrane stays behind and becomes part of the cell membrane.

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic man is started on an insulin secretagogue. Which of the following ions is required for emeiocytosis or reverse pinocytosis during the insulin secretion process?
questions.solution:
Emeiocytosis requires Ca2+ directly.

Emeiocytosis is the movement of secretory granules to the plasma membrane of the cell, fusion of the granule surface membrane with the cell membrane, rupture of membranes, and liberation of granular contents into the pericapillary space. 

Insulin secretion (as shown in the image below):

  • Glucose enters B cells by GLUT-2 transporters.
  • It is phosphorylated and metabolized to pyruvate (Pyr) in the cytoplasm.
  • The Pyr enters the mitochondria and is metabolized via the citric acid cycle. The ATP formed by oxidative phosphorylation inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels, reducing K+ efflux.
  • This depolarizes the B cell, and Ca2+ influx is increased. The Ca2+ stimulates the release of insulin by exocytosis. Glutamate (Glu) is also formed, and this primes secretory granules, preparing them for exocytosis.

It is promoted by Ca2+,  ↑ K+

It is inhibited by Mg2+, K+ depletion.
